name: INSERT
shortDescription: Insert new rows into a table
description: Insert one or more rows into an Elasticsearch index. Uses the Bulk API for efficient batch inserts. If the table has a PRIMARY KEY, duplicate keys will update existing documents (upsert behavior).

clauses.name: column list
clauses.description: Optional list of columns to insert. If omitted, all columns must be provided in order.

clauses.name: VALUES
clauses.description: One or more value tuples to insert

clauses.name: SELECT
clauses.description: Insert results from a SELECT query

examples.title: Insert single row
examples.sql:
INSERT INTO users (id, name, email)
VALUES (1, 'Alice', 'alice@example.com')

examples.title: Insert multiple rows
examples.sql:
INSERT INTO users (id, name, email) VALUES
  (1, 'Alice', 'alice@example.com'),
  (2, 'Bob', 'bob@example.com'),
  (3, 'Charlie', 'charlie@example.com')

examples.title: Insert with struct
examples.sql:
INSERT INTO users (id, name, profile) VALUES
  (1, 'Alice', {city = 'Paris', followers = 100})

examples.title: Insert with array
examples.description: Insert document with array of nested objects

examples.title: Insert from SELECT
examples.sql:
INSERT INTO archive_users
SELECT * FROM users WHERE created_at < '2024-01-01'

examples.title: Insert with specific columns
examples.description: Insert only specified columns (others get defaults)

notes: If table has a PRIMARY KEY, it will be used as document _id
Duplicate _id will update existing document (upsert behavior)
Batch inserts use the Bulk API for better performance
DEFAULT values are applied by the ingest pipeline
NULL values are inserted as missing fields
